choices: Fire ant bites rarely cause anaphylaxis.
Fire ants often bite a person repeatedly.
Fire ant bites typically occur on the face.
Most people are allergic to fire ant toxin.
front.question: Which of the following statements regarding fire ants is correct?
front.source: See Common Allergens

cards.back: Fire ants often bite a person repeatedly.

choices: record the time and dose given.
notify medical control of your action.
front.question: Immediately after giving an epinephrine injection, you should:
front.source: See Emergency Medical Care of Immunologic Emergencies

choices: A direct negative effect on the body by an external substance
An exaggerated immune system response to any substance
Destruction of the immune system by an external substance
A release of erythrocytes in response to a foreign substance
front.question: Which of the following MOST accurately defines an allergic reaction?
front.source: See Pathophysiology

cards.back: An exaggerated immune system response to any substance

front.question: When administering epinephrine via auto-injector, you should hold the injector in place for:
front.source: See Emergency Medical Care of Immunologic Emergencies

front.question: A raised, swollen, well-defined area on the skin that is the result of an insect bite or sting is called:
front.source: See Common Allergens

front.question: The foreign substance responsible for causing an allergic reaction is called a(n):
front.source: See Pathophysiology

front.question: Urticaria is the medical term for:
front.source: See Pathophysiology

front.question: When an auto-injector is used to give epinephrine, the primary injection site is the:
front.source: See Emergency Medical Care of Immunologic Emergencies

choices: place her supine with her legs elevated.
locate the area where the fire ants bit her.
front.question: A 38-year-old woman was bitten by fire ants while at the park. Your primary assessment reveals that she is semiconscious; has labored breathing; and has a rapid, thready pulse. She has a red rash on her entire body, and her face is swollen. You should:
front.source: See Patient Assessment of an Immunologic Emergency

front.question: Which of the following sounds indicates swelling of the upper airway?
front.source: See Patient Assessment of an Immunologic Emergency

choices: enlargement of the bronchioles in the lungs.
a significant amount of fluid in the alveoli.
rapid swelling of the upper airway tissues.
narrowing of the bronchioles in the lungs.
front.question: While auscultating breath sounds of a patient who was stung multiple times by a yellow jacket, you hear bilateral wheezing over all lung fields. This indicates:
front.source: See Patient Assessment of an Immunologic Emergency

cards.back: narrowing of the bronchioles in the lungs.

choices: irrigated with copious amounts of water.
front.question: The stinger from a honeybee should be:
front.source: See Common Allergens

front.question: Two of the MOST common signs of anaphylaxis are:
front.source: See Pathophysiology

choices: the patient is anxious and tachycardic.
a paramedic is present at the scene.
front.question: Epinephrine is indicated for patients with an allergic reaction when:
front.source: See Emergency Medical Care of Immunologic Emergencies

front.question: Which of the following negative effects of anaphylaxis will be the MOST rapidly fatal if not treated immediately?
front.source: See Patient Assessment of an Immunologic Emergency

front.question: The effects of epinephrine are typically observed within _________ following administration.
front.source: See Emergency Medical Care of Immunologic Emergencies

front.question: Common signs and symptoms of an allergic reaction include all of the following, EXCEPT:
front.source: See Patient Assessment of an Immunologic Emergency

choices: A 30-year-old male who was stung by a bee
A 50-year-old male who was exposed to latex
front.question: Which of the following patients would MOST likely have a delayed onset of an allergic reaction?
front.source: See Common Allergens

choices: The environment in which the patient is found
The time of year in which the exposure occurred
front.question: Which of the following would MOST likely provide clues regarding the source of a patient’s allergic reaction?
front.source: See Patient Assessment of an Immunologic Emergency

cards.back: The environment in which the patient is found

front.question: Chemicals that are responsible for the signs and symptoms of an allergic reaction to a bee sting include:
front.source: See Pathophysiology
